page.title: 10Local History - South Scarle
page.content: There is little of the eleventh century church visible. Two impressive late Norman arches are present in the nave, it being complete in early English style together with a tower and chancel. The clerestory, north and south arches are of the Perpendicular period. There is a fine Medieval timbered ceiling to the nave ornanented with angels, shields and bosses. The roof of the chancel is nineteenth century. The prebendary estate no longer exists having been intergrated into the local farms and grounds. Six acres of the churches land are now the only remnants and are now under the control of the secular 'Parish meeting'. They are rented out to local farmers. The parish is now combined with those of Besthorpe and Girton, and united into a single benefice with the Collingham churches.
